subject: Entrepreneurship
courseTitle: Business Models That Changed the World

topics.title: The Rise of Platform Business Models

hook.text: In 2007 Nokia was the world's most valuable phone company. By 2013, platforms had eaten it alive.

buildup.text: A platform connects producers and consumers. It doesn't make the productâ€”it makes the connection.

discovery.text: Uber owns no cars. Airbnb owns no hotels. Facebook creates no content. They're all platforms.

twist.text: Traditional companies create value in a pipeline. Platforms let others create value for them.

climax.text: Seven of the ten most valuable companies in the world are now platform businesses.

punchline.text: The biggest hotel chain owns no rooms.

quiz.question: What makes a platform business model different from traditional businesses?
options: It connects producers and consumers instead of making the product itself
It always offers free products to users
It requires massive upfront inventory investment

hook.text: Travis Kalanick couldn't get a cab on a snowy Paris night. That frustration launched a $70 billion company.

buildup.text: Uber didn't buy cars or hire drivers. It built software that matched riders with drivers in minutes.

discovery.text: Dynamic pricingâ€”surge pricingâ€”was Uber's secret weapon. Higher prices attracted more drivers instantly.

twist.text: Taxi medallions in New York once cost $1.3 million. After Uber, some sold for under $200,000.

climax.text: Uber proved that owning assets isn't needed to dominate an industryâ€”owning the algorithm is.

punchline.text: One app replaced an entire industry's infrastructure.

quiz.question: What was Uber's key innovation in the transportation industry?
options: Building a fleet of luxury vehicles
Using software to match riders and drivers without owning vehicles
Offering lower prices than public transit

topics.title: Airbnb: Spare Rooms to Global Empire

hook.text: Three broke designers rented air mattresses in their apartment to afford rent. That was Airbnb day one.

buildup.text: They saw something nobody else did: millions of empty rooms and millions of travelers needing them.

discovery.text: Trust was the breakthrough. Reviews, verified photos, and host profiles turned strangers into hosts.

twist.text: Hotels lobbied against Airbnb, but guests preferred staying in real homes over sterile lobbies.

climax.text: Airbnb now lists more rooms than the top five hotel chains combinedâ€”without owning a single one.

punchline.text: Spare bedrooms became the world's largest hotel.

quiz.question: What was Airbnb's biggest challenge in building its marketplace?
options: Finding enough rooms to list on the platform
Building trust between strangers through reviews and verification
Competing with hotels on price alone

hook.text: Amazon started as a bookstore. Today over 60% of its sales come from third-party sellers.

buildup.text: Jeff Bezos drew the flywheel on a napkin: lower prices attract buyers, buyers attract sellers.

discovery.text: More sellers meant more selection. More selection meant more buyers. More buyers attracted more sellers.

twist.text: Amazon competes with its own sellers. It uses their data to launch competing private-label products.

climax.text: The flywheel spins faster over time. Each revolution makes it harder for competitors to keep up.

punchline.text: The store that sells everything built itself on others' inventory.

quiz.question: What is the core idea behind Amazon's flywheel?
options: Spending heavily on advertising to attract customers
Lower prices attract buyers, buyers attract sellers, creating a self-reinforcing cycle
Offering the fastest delivery times in the industry

hook.text: Encyclopedia Britannica had 4,000 paid experts. Wikipedia had millions of free volunteersâ€”and won.

buildup.text: Pipeline businesses create value step by step: design, make, sell. Platforms let users do the creating.

discovery.text: Platforms scale at near-zero marginal cost. Adding one more user costs almost nothing.

twist.text: The best platforms don't compete with pipelines. They make pipelines compete with each other.

climax.text: When a platform reaches critical mass, switching costs lock users in and lock competitors out.

punchline.text: Don't build the factory. Build the marketplace.

quiz.question: Why do platforms scale more efficiently than pipeline businesses?
options: They always have better products than traditional companies
They pay workers less than pipeline businesses do
Adding each new user costs almost nothing because users create the value

hook.text: Your grandparents bought a razor once. You subscribe to one. Subscriptions now rule the economy.

buildup.text: Subscriptions aren't newâ€”newspapers used them for centuries. But software reinvented the concept.

discovery.text: Instead of one big payment, companies get small recurring ones. Predictable revenue changes everything.

twist.text: The average American now has 12 paid subscriptions. Most people underestimate how many they carry.

climax.text: Subscription businesses are valued higher by investors because future revenue is nearly guaranteed.

punchline.text: Owning things is out. Subscribing to everything is in.

quiz.question: Why do investors value subscription businesses higher than one-time-sale businesses?
options: Subscriptions always cost less to produce
Recurring revenue is predictable and nearly guaranteed
Subscription customers never cancel their plans

hook.text: Blockbuster had 9,000 stores and laughed when Netflix offered to sell for $50 million.

buildup.text: Netflix started mailing DVDs with no late fees. Blockbuster's $800 million in late fees was its weakness.

discovery.text: Then Netflix pivoted to streamingâ€”a subscription model that eliminated shipping costs entirely.

twist.text: Blockbuster launched its own streaming service. But it was too lateâ€”Netflix had the subscriber base.

climax.text: By 2010, Blockbuster filed for bankruptcy. Netflix now has over 200 million subscribers worldwide.

punchline.text: The giant laughed, then the giant fell.

quiz.question: What was Blockbuster's biggest vulnerability that Netflix exploited?
options: Blockbuster's stores were in bad locations
Blockbuster relied heavily on late fees that customers hated
Blockbuster didn't have enough movie titles

topics.title: SaaS: Software You Rent, Not Own

hook.text: Companies once spent millions installing software on servers. Now they swipe a credit card monthly.

buildup.text: SaaSâ€”Software as a Serviceâ€”delivers apps over the internet. No installation, no upfront cost.

discovery.text: Salesforce was the pioneer. Marc Benioff's motto was 'No Software'â€”meaning no installed software.

twist.text: SaaS companies can update features for every customer at once. Traditional software can't.

climax.text: The SaaS model turned software from a product you buy into a relationship you maintain.

punchline.text: Software stopped being a purchase. It became a relationship.

quiz.question: What key advantage does the SaaS model offer over traditional software?
options: SaaS software is always faster than installed software
SaaS eliminates upfront costs and delivers updates to all users instantly
SaaS products never require customer support

hook.text: A comedian made a $4,500 video about razors. It got 12,000 orders in two days.

buildup.text: Michael Dubin saw that Gillette charged $6 per blade for a product that costs pennies to make.

discovery.text: Dollar Shave Club shipped basic razors monthly for $1. No fancy techâ€”just better pricing and convenience.

twist.text: Gillette owned 70% of the razor market. Within five years, it dropped to 54% because of DSC.

climax.text: Unilever bought Dollar Shave Club for $1 billionâ€”proving subscriptions could disrupt any industry.

punchline.text: A dollar razor cut a billion-dollar giant down to size.

quiz.question: Why was Dollar Shave Club able to disrupt Gillette's dominance?
options: It invented a superior razor blade technology
It offered a convenient subscription at a fraction of the price
It partnered with major retail chains for distribution

hook.text: A gym makes money from people who don't show up. That's the power of recurring revenue.

buildup.text: One-time sales force you to constantly find new customers. Subscriptions keep old ones paying.

discovery.text: Metrics like MRR, churn rate, and lifetime value let subscription companies predict future income.

twist.text: A 5% improvement in retention can increase profits by 25-95%. Keeping beats acquiring.

climax.text: Wall Street values recurring revenue up to 8x higher than one-time sales of the same amount.

punchline.text: The best sale is the one that renews itself.

quiz.question: Why is recurring revenue valued so much higher than one-time sales?
options: It costs less to deliver products to subscribers
It makes future income predictable and compounds with retention
Subscribers always spend more per transaction

hook.text: Spotify has 600 million users but only 220 million pay. The free users aren't a lossâ€”they're the strategy.

buildup.text: Freemium gives a basic product away free, then charges for premium features or upgrades.

discovery.text: Free users become marketing. Every person using Spotify tells friends, who might eventually pay.

twist.text: Most freemium products convert only 2-5% of users to paid. That tiny slice funds the entire platform.

climax.text: The model works because digital products cost almost nothing to serve one more free user.

punchline.text: Give it away free. Make money from the few who want more.

quiz.question: What is the typical paid conversion rate for freemium products?
options: About 25-50% of all users
About 2-5% of all users
About 75-90% of all users

hook.text: Google's search engine is free. Yet Google makes over $200 billion a year. How?

buildup.text: Every search you make reveals what you want. That intent data is incredibly valuable to advertisers.

discovery.text: Google Ads works on an auction system. Businesses bid to appear when you search specific keywords.

twist.text: You think you're Google's customer. You're notâ€”you're the product. Advertisers are the real customers.

climax.text: Google captures over 90% of global search traffic, making its ad platform nearly impossible to rival.

punchline.text: The world's best ad company disguised itself as a search engine.

quiz.question: How does Google primarily make money from its free search engine?
options: By selling user data directly to third parties
By charging businesses to appear in auction-based search ads
By licensing its search technology to other companies

hook.text: Spotify pays artists per stream but lets millions listen for free. The math seems impossible.

buildup.text: Free users hear ads between songs. That ad revenue covers some costs but not all.

discovery.text: The real play is conversion. Free users get hooked, then upgrade to premium to skip ads.

twist.text: Spotify's biggest expense isn't technologyâ€”it's paying record labels 70% of every dollar earned.

climax.text: With over 220 million paid subscribers, Spotify proved freemium scales even in costly industries.

punchline.text: Free music was never free. It was a trial that never expired.

quiz.question: What is Spotify's biggest operational expense?
options: Server infrastructure and technology costs
Marketing and user acquisition spending
Paying record labels roughly 70% of revenue

topics.title: Social Media: You Are the Product

hook.text: Facebook is free to use. It's also worth over $800 billion. You're not the customerâ€”you're the inventory.

buildup.text: Social media companies collect your attention, preferences, and behaviorâ€”then sell access to advertisers.

discovery.text: The average person spends 2.5 hours daily on social media. That attention is the real product being sold.

twist.text: The algorithm doesn't show you what's true. It shows you what keeps you scrollingâ€”outrage works best.

climax.text: Ad-supported social media created the most profitable business model in historyâ€”and the most debated.

punchline.text: If you're not paying for it, you're what's being sold.

quiz.question: Why do social media algorithms tend to promote outrage-inducing content?
options: Outrage keeps users scrolling longer, which increases ad revenue
Social media companies want to inform users about important issues
Controversial content is cheaper to produce and distribute

topics.title: Why Free Is the Most Expensive Price

hook.text: Chris Anderson wrote that the future of business is giving things away. Not everyone agreed.

buildup.text: Free products dominate markets. Free email killed paid email. Free maps killed GPS devices.

discovery.text: When something is free, the company must monetize another way: ads, data, or upsells.

twist.text: Free can destroy industries. Craigslist wiped out $25 billion in newspaper classified ad revenue.

climax.text: Free creates massive user bases fast, but it also trains customers to never want to pay.

punchline.text: Free costs nothing to the userâ€”and everything to competitors.

quiz.question: What is the biggest risk of the 'free' business model?
options: Free products always have lower quality than paid ones
It trains customers to expect everything for free, making monetization harder
Free products cannot legally collect user data

hook.text: King Gillette gave away razors for free in 1904. Everyone thought he was crazyâ€”until the blades sold.

buildup.text: The razor-blade model sells the base product cheap, then profits from the consumables that go with it.

discovery.text: Gillette's razors locked customers into buying proprietary blades. The handle was just a delivery device.

twist.text: The model is everywhereâ€”cheap printers with expensive ink, cheap consoles with expensive games.

climax.text: Customers think they got a deal on the razor. They end up spending ten times more on blades.

punchline.text: The handle is the trap. The blade is the profit.

quiz.question: What is the core principle of the razor-blade business model?
options: Sell premium products at premium prices for maximum margin
Give away or discount the base product, then profit from consumables
Bundle the razor and blades together at a single high price

topics.title: Printer Ink: The Real Money Machine

hook.text: Printer ink costs more per ounce than champagne, perfume, or even human blood.

buildup.text: HP sells printers at or below cost. The profit comes entirely from replacement ink cartridges.

discovery.text: HP designed cartridges with chips that block third-party ink. The printer enforces the business model.

twist.text: HP's ink division generates more profit than many Fortune 500 companiesâ€”from a product that costs pennies.

climax.text: Consumers fought back with refill kits and lawsuits, but HP's lock-in strategy still dominates.

punchline.text: The cheapest printer in the store is the most expensive to own.

quiz.question: How does HP enforce its razor-blade model with printers?
options: By offering free printer repairs to loyal customers
By embedding chips in cartridges that block third-party ink
By requiring annual subscriptions for printer software

hook.text: Keurig sells a coffee maker for $100. But each tiny cup of coffee costs more per pound than Starbucks.

buildup.text: The K-Cup was designed to make single-serve coffee convenient. Convenience created the lock-in.

discovery.text: Each K-Cup costs 50 cents but contains just 10 cents of coffee. The pod is the real product.

twist.text: When Keurig added DRM to block third-party pods, customers revolted and sales dropped 23%.

climax.text: Keurig reversed course, but the lesson stuck: razor-blade models fail when customers feel cheated.

punchline.text: Convenience is the lock. The pod is the key to profits.

quiz.question: What happened when Keurig added DRM to block third-party coffee pods?
options: Sales increased because customers trusted the quality more
Customers revolted and Keurig's sales dropped significantly
Third-party pod makers went out of business

topics.title: Gaming Consoles: Sell Hardware, Win on Software

hook.text: Sony sold the PlayStation 3 at a $200 loss per unit. It was the most expensive product they subsidized.

buildup.text: Console makers sell hardware cheap to build an install base. The real money comes from game licenses.

discovery.text: Every game sold on PlayStation pays Sony a 30% royalty. Millions of games sold means billions in fees.

twist.text: Microsoft's Xbox Game Pass flipped the scriptâ€”subscription revenue instead of per-game royalties.

climax.text: The console war isn't about hardware specs. It's about who controls the ecosystem where games are sold.

punchline.text: The console is the bait. Every game sold is the hook.

quiz.question: Why do console makers like Sony sell hardware at a loss?
options: To undercut PC gaming prices and steal market share
To build an install base and profit from game license royalties
Because manufacturing costs always decrease over time

hook.text: Dollar Shave Club proved that razor blades don't need to be expensive. Gillette's lock-in shattered.

buildup.text: The razor-blade model works only when customers can't easily find alternatives.

discovery.text: Three forces break the model: third-party alternatives, customer backlash, and regulatory pressure.

twist.text: Keurig, HP, and Gillette all faced revolts. Customers found generic pods, refilled ink, and switched brands.

climax.text: The internet made it easy to find cheaper alternatives, weakening lock-in strategies everywhere.

punchline.text: Lock-in worksâ€”until customers find the exit.

quiz.question: What is the biggest threat to the razor-blade business model?
options: Rising manufacturing costs for the base product
Easy access to third-party alternatives and informed consumers
Government bans on consumable products

hook.text: A telephone is useless if nobody else has one. Add a million users and it becomes essential.

buildup.text: Network effects mean a product gets more valuable as more people use it.

discovery.text: Facebook with 10 users is pointless. Facebook with 2 billion users is where everyone's friends are.

twist.text: Network effects create winner-take-all markets. The biggest network attracts even more users.

climax.text: Metcalfe's Law says a network's value grows proportionally to the square of its users.

punchline.text: Every new user makes it better for every other user.

quiz.question: What does Metcalfe's Law describe about network effects?
options: A network's cost increases linearly with each new user
A network's value grows proportionally to the square of its users
A network always reaches a maximum of one million users

hook.text: In 1995, strangers sent money to other strangers online for used goods. Everyone said it was insane.

buildup.text: eBay's challenge wasn't technology. It was trustâ€”how do you buy from someone you've never met?

discovery.text: The star rating system was eBay's breakthrough. Reputation became currency in the digital marketplace.

twist.text: Sellers with perfect ratings earned 8% more than sellers with 98% ratings. Trust premiums are real.

climax.text: eBay proved that trust systems can replace physical stores. Every marketplace since has copied them.

punchline.text: Stars and reviews replaced handshakes and storefronts.

quiz.question: What was eBay's most important innovation for online commerce?
options: Offering the lowest prices on all products
Creating a reputation and rating system that built trust between strangers
Providing free shipping on all marketplace transactions

hook.text: Apple didn't make Candy Crush. But it took 30 cents of every dollar the game earned.

buildup.text: The App Store is a marketplace where Apple sets the rules, controls access, and collects a toll.

discovery.text: Developers get distribution to a billion devices. In return, Apple takes 30% of every transaction.

twist.text: Epic Games sued Apple over the 30% cut. The trial revealed the App Store's 78% profit margin.

climax.text: Regulators worldwide now question whether app store fees are fair or monopolistic.

punchline.text: Build the marketplace, then charge tolls at every door.

quiz.question: Why did Epic Games sue Apple over the App Store?
options: Apple refused to feature Fortnite on the App Store
Epic challenged Apple's 30% commission as anti-competitive
Apple copied Epic's game design without permission

hook.text: A potter in rural Vermont couldn't sell beyond her town. Etsy connected her to buyers in Tokyo.

buildup.text: Etsy created a marketplace specifically for handmade and vintage goodsâ€”a niche Amazon didn't serve.

discovery.text: By focusing on artisans, Etsy attracted sellers who valued community and buyers who valued uniqueness.

twist.text: As Etsy grew, factory-made goods flooded in. The 'handmade' identity that built Etsy started to erode.

climax.text: Etsy proved niche marketplaces can thriveâ€”but success always tempts you to abandon what made you special.

punchline.text: A niche marketplace thrives until it tries to be everything.

quiz.question: What challenge did Etsy face as it grew larger?
options: It couldn't attract enough buyers to the platform
Factory-made goods flooded in and eroded its handmade identity
Artisans refused to pay Etsy's listing fees

hook.text: MySpace had 100 million users in 2008. By 2011, it was a ghost town. Facebook ate it alive.

buildup.text: Network effects create winner-take-all markets. The leader grows faster, the followers starve.

discovery.text: Once a platform crosses critical mass, users can't leave because everyone else is already there.

twist.text: But winner-take-all isn't permanent. TikTok proved a newcomer can steal attention from Facebook.

climax.text: The moat around a platform isn't code. It's the social graphâ€”and social graphs can shift overnight.

punchline.text: Today's unstoppable giant is tomorrow's MySpace.

quiz.question: Why aren't winner-take-all dynamics permanent in platform markets?
options: Governments always break up dominant platforms eventually
Users' attention and social graphs can shift to new platforms quickly
Dominant platforms always raise prices and lose customers

hook.text: Warby Parker sells glasses for $95 that cost the same as $400 frames from Luxottica.

buildup.text: DTC brands skip retailers and sell straight to customers online, keeping margins for themselves.

discovery.text: Without middlemen, DTC brands control pricing, branding, and the customer relationship directly.

twist.text: Many DTC darlings burned cash on ads to acquire customers. Growth was expensive, not free.

climax.text: Casper, Allbirds, and Peloton all went publicâ€”then struggled. DTC alone isn't a moat.

punchline.text: Skip the middleman, but don't forget you still need a moat.

quiz.question: What is the main advantage of the direct-to-consumer model?
options: DTC brands never need to spend money on marketing
Skipping retailers lets brands control pricing and the customer relationship
DTC products are always higher quality than retail alternatives

hook.text: Airbnb and Uber promised a world of sharing. But most hosts and drivers are running businesses.

buildup.text: The sharing economy was supposed to unlock idle assetsâ€”spare rooms, empty car seats, unused tools.

discovery.text: In reality, professional hosts own multiple Airbnb properties. Full-time drivers dominate Uber.

twist.text: The 'sharing' economy became the 'gig' economy. Workers traded stability for flexibility they didn't want.

climax.text: Platforms captured most of the value while workers bore the riskâ€”no benefits, no protections.

punchline.text: They called it sharing. It was renting with an app.

quiz.question: How did the sharing economy differ from its original promise?
options: It became dominated by professionals rather than casual sharers of idle assets
It failed because consumers didn't trust the platform model
It was shut down by government regulations worldwide

topics.title: Open Source: Free Software, Big Business

hook.text: Linux powers 96% of the world's top servers. It's completely free. And companies make billions from it.

buildup.text: Open source gives away the code and charges for support, hosting, or enterprise features.

discovery.text: Red Hat built a billion-dollar business selling support for free software. IBM bought it for $34 billion.

twist.text: Microsoft once called Linux a cancer. Then it bought GitHub and became open source's biggest contributor.

climax.text: The open-source model proves that giving away your product can be the smartest business strategy of all.

punchline.text: Give away the code. Sell everything around it.

quiz.question: How did Red Hat build a billion-dollar business with free software?
options: By secretly making its version of Linux proprietary
By selling enterprise support and services around free open-source software
By charging licensing fees for each Linux download

hook.text: Google doesn't create content. Facebook doesn't write posts. Yet they captured all the ad revenue.

buildup.text: Ben Thompson's Aggregation Theory explains how the internet lets certain companies dominate industries.

discovery.text: Aggregators win by owning the customer relationship. Suppliers become interchangeable and commoditized.

twist.text: Hotels compete for your booking on Expedia. Expedia doesn't competeâ€”it just takes a cut from everyone.

climax.text: The aggregator sits between supply and demand, capturing value from both sides without creating either.

punchline.text: Own the customer. Let everyone else fight for scraps.

quiz.question: What is the key power of an aggregator according to Aggregation Theory?
options: Producing the best content or products in the market
Owning the customer relationship while commoditizing suppliers
Offering the lowest prices by eliminating all middlemen

topics.title: What Makes a Business Model Truly Disruptive?

hook.text: Clayton Christensen coined 'disruptive innovation.' Most people who use the term get it completely wrong.

buildup.text: True disruption starts at the bottom of a marketâ€”cheap, simple products that incumbents ignore.

discovery.text: The disruptor improves over time and moves upmarket. By the time the incumbent notices, it's too late.

twist.text: Uber isn't disruptive by Christensen's definition. It targeted mainstream customers from day one.

climax.text: Real disruption sneaks in quietly. The products start bad, get better, and eventually replace the giant.

punchline.text: The most dangerous competitor is the one you laughed at.

quiz.question: According to Clayton Christensen, how does true disruption begin?
options: By launching a superior product that beats the incumbent immediately
By starting at the bottom of a market with cheap, simple products incumbents ignore
By raising massive venture capital to outspend competitors
